elements.content: A rigid pyridine-3,5-bis­(5-aza­benz­imidazole) ligand (L) and linear dicarboxylate sodium terephthalate (TPA) with Cd­(II), Zn­(II), and Co­(II) under solvothermal conditions afforded water stable and nitrogen-rich MOFs with general formulas [Cd2 L 2­(TPA)2]·12H2O} n , 1, {[Zn4 L 4­(TPA)4]·(DMF)·16H2O} n , 2, and {[Co2 L 2­(TPA)2]·12H2O} n , 3, respectively. These MOFs are found to contain doubly interpenetrated pcu networks with hydrophilic channels. The networks are propagated by M2­(CO2)2 SBUs (intermetallic distances 4.0 Å) which leads to the formation of a two-dimensional grid structure of metal-terephthalate. The shape of grids varies from rhomboidal to squaric depending on the presence of a metal center. The channels of these MOFs are occupied by the one-dimensional water cages. In the pcu network, each cuboid is found to have dimensions of ∼12.5 Å as width and 18.5 Å as length. They have shown an excellent ability for water vapor sorption (180–225 cc/g at 298 K). Further, CO2 is found to be the preferred sorbent (70 cc/g at 273 K) over N2. They were also shown to be capable of dye (methylene blue and crystal violet) removal from aqueous solutions through adsorption. Further, Cd­(II) and Zn­(II) MOFs are found to exhibit solid state luminescence properties.

elements.content: Three MOFs of Cd­(II), Zn­(II), and Co­(II) have been synthesized using a new hydrophilic ligand and sodium terephthalate. The crystal structures reveal the formation of a 3D-network with pcu topology and inclusion of one-dimensional water cages. These MOFs have shown the propensity to adsorb water vapor, CO2, and cationic dyes.
elements.clean_text: Three MOFs of Cd(II), Zn(II), and Co(II) have been synthesized using a new hydrophilic ligand and sodium terephthalate. The crystal structures reveal the formation of a 3D-network with pcu topology and inclusion of one-dimensional water cages. These MOFs have shown the propensity to adsorb water vapor, CO2, and cationic dyes.

elements.content: The burning of fossil fuel creates significant problems to the human civilization due to the evolution of CO2 gases. Carbon dioxide (CO2) acquisition in the atmosphere creates a greenhouse effect as it raises pollution and global warming. The rising level of anthropogenic carbon dioxide (CO2) has a direct impact on our environment. The capturing of CO2 from the atmosphere is being considered as one of the effective methods for the reduction of greenhouse effects. In this regard, the design of the materials capable of adsorption of CO2 gases had gained great attention. MOFs have been regarded as one of those potential adsorbents given their designable structures, porosity, high surface area, large pore volume, and facile pore functionalization. Therefore, several recent studies on MOFs have been focused on fabricating frameworks with large pores and high surface areas. One of the main focuses of the area is selective sorption of CO2 over N2 or CH4 by the exploitation of a series of MOFs that are synthesized by the change of metal ions or by changing the nature of pores through various functionalizations on the organic part.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The burning of fossil fuel creates significant problems to the human civilization due to the evolution of CO2 gases. Carbon dioxide (CO2) acquisition in the atmosphere creates a greenhouse effect as it raises pollution and global warming. The rising level of anthropogenic carbon dioxide (CO2) has a direct impact on our environment. The capturing of CO2 from the atmosphere is being considered as one of the effective methods for the reduction of greenhouse effects. In this regard, the design of the materials capable of adsorption of CO2 gases had gained great attention. MOFs have been regarded as one of those potential adsorbents given their designable structures, porosity, high surface area, large pore volume, and facile pore functionalization. Therefore, several recent studies on MOFs have been focused on fabricating frameworks with large pores and high surface areas. One of the main focuses of the area is selective sorption of CO2 over N2 or CH4 by the exploitation of a series of MOFs that are synthesized by the change of metal ions or by changing the nature of pores through various functionalizations on the organic part.

elements.content: Several MOFs have been reported so far for CO2 adsorption and selectivity utilizing organic ligands containing carboxylate, imidazole, tetrazole, triazole, or pyrazole moieties. The Yaghi group had explored zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) for the adsorption of the gases and concluded that the pore size has a little effect for the selective sorption of CO2 gas, while the interaction of gas with the framework plays a significant role in the selective sorption of the gases. A family of CPM-33 MOFs were shown to exhibit superior CO2 adsorption–desorption capacity. However, there are no previous reports on exploiting the MOFs containing azabenzimidazole for such purposes.
elements.clean_text: Several MOFs have been reported so far for CO2 adsorption and selectivity utilizing organic ligands containing carboxylate, imidazole, tetrazole, triazole, or pyrazole moieties. The Yaghi group had explored zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) for the adsorption of the gases and concluded that the pore size has a little effect for the selective sorption of CO2 gas, while the interaction of gas with the framework plays a significant role in the selective sorption of the gases. A family of CPM-33 MOFs were shown to exhibit superior CO2 adsorption-desorption capacity. However, there are no previous reports on exploiting the MOFs containing azabenzimidazole for such purposes.

elements.content: The metal carboxylate binding is known to form several SBUs to propagate 3D-framework structures. Among those, the most utilized and attractive are six connected metal tetrahedrons with M4(O)­(carboxylate)6 and butterfly motif with M2­(carboxylate)4. The coordination unsaturation of the metal carboxylate SBUs can be utilized further for the binding of neutral ligands containing bipyridyl/​imidazoles/​pyrazole, and in effect the dimensionality of the network can be enhanced. Generally, the curved nature of the ligands is expected to result in the formation of voids for the incorporation of guest molecules. Recently, we have reported the use of curved bis­(aza­benz­imidazole) ligands and curved dicarboxylates in producing 2D-networks which have a capability for inclusion of water molecules and water vapor sorption. However, in these networks, the angular dicarboxylates consistently formed metal-carboxylate 1D-chains consisting of SBUs of M2­(COO)2. The ligand L has exhibited the propensity to link such 1D-chains to 2D-layers. From these results, it is envisaged that the use of linear dicarboxylates may result in the formation of 2D-layers of metal carboxylate that can be linked by L to 3D-networks, MOFs. These MOFs can be regarded as N-rich systems as they contain as many as seven N atoms (two are imines) per ligand which create hydrophilic cavities. MOFs with such cavities are important to capture water molecules and to stabilize water clusters with various geometries within the channels/​cavities.

Among those, the most utilized and attractive are six connected metal tetrahedrons with M4(O)(carboxylate)6 and butterfly motif with M2(carboxylate)4. The coordination unsaturation of the metal carboxylate SBUs can be utilized further for the binding of neutral ligands containing bipyridyl/imidazoles/pyrazole, and in effect the dimensionality of the network can be enhanced. Generally, the curved nature of the ligands is expected to result in the formation of voids for the incorporation of guest molecules. Recently, we have reported the use of curved bis(azabenzimidazole) ligands and curved dicarboxylates in producing 2D-networks which have a capability for inclusion of water molecules and water vapor sorption. However, in these networks, the angular dicarboxylates consistently formed metal-carboxylate 1D-chains consisting of SBUs of M2(COO)2. The ligand L has exhibited the propensity to link such 1D-chains to 2D-layers. From these results, it is envisaged that the use of linear dicarboxylates may result in the formation of 2D-layers of metal carboxylate that can be linked by L to 3D-networks, MOFs. These MOFs can be regarded as N-rich systems as they contain as many as seven N atoms (two are imines) per ligand which create hydrophilic cavities. MOFs with such cavities are important to capture water molecules and to stabilize water clusters with various geometries within the channels/cavities.

elements.content: The study of the geometry of water clusters is of importance as they have implications in understanding bulk water behavior. A variety of water clusters have been reported to date include hexagons, pentagons, one-dimensional networks, two-dimensional layers, and three-dimensional networks; all of these are encapsulated/templated by a host network of CPs. The water stability of the MOFs is another important aspect that is detrimental for its industrial use as an adsorbent material.

A variety of water clusters have been reported to date include hexagons, pentagons, one-dimensional networks, two-dimensional layers, and three-dimensional networks; all of these are encapsulated/templated by a host network of CPs. The water stability of the MOFs is another important aspect that is detrimental for its industrial use as an adsorbent material.

elements.content: Herein, we would like to report our studies on MOFs of L and terephthalate and their gas sorption properties. The complexation reactions of L and sodium terephthalate with Cd­(II) or Zn­(II) or Co­(II) metal salts have been conducted in a solvothermal process to obtain the single crystal of the corresponding MOFs (). All the three MOFs are found to contain a plethora of water molecules in their channels and found to exhibit water sorption. Further, these materials have shown selective sorption of CO2 over N2 gas. The Cd­(II) and Zn­(II) MOFs have exhibited excellent luminescence properties at room temperature.

elements.content: The ligand L was synthesized by simple condensation reaction between 3,4-diamino pyridine and pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid. The single crystals of MOFs (1–3) were obtained by the solvothermal reaction of L, sodium terephthalate and Cd­(NO3)2 or Zn­(NO3)2 or Co­(NO3)2 in DMF/H2O or DMA/H2O at 100 °C. The single crystal diffraction analyses reveal that the complexes 1–3 have formulas [Cd2 L 2­(TPA)2]·12H2O} n , {[Zn4 L 4­(TPA)4]·(DMF)·16H2O} n , and {[Co2 L 2­(TPA)2]·12H2O} n , respectively. The crystal structure analysis suggests that all three are isostructural and contain doubly interpenetrated 3D-networks containing pcu topology. The pertinent crystallographic information is given in .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The ligand L was synthesized by simple condensation reaction between 3,4-diamino pyridine and pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid. The single crystals of MOFs (1-3) were obtained by the solvothermal reaction of L, sodium terephthalate and Cd(NO3)2 or Zn(NO3)2 or Co(NO3)2 in DMF/H2O or DMA/H2O at 100 °C. The single crystal diffraction analyses reveal that the complexes 1-3 have formulas [Cd2 L 2(TPA)2]⋅12H2O} n , {[Zn4 L 4(TPA)4]⋅(DMF)⋅16H2O} n , and {[Co2 L 2(TPA)2]⋅12H2O} n , respectively. The crystal structure analysis suggests that all three are isostructural and contain doubly interpenetrated 3D-networks containing pcu topology. The pertinent crystallographic information is given in .

The complexes 1–3 crystallize in a monoclinic crystal system and exhibit isostructurality. The complexes 1 and 3 exhibit P2­(1)/c, while 2 exhibits P2­(1) space group. The asymmetric units of 1 and 3 are constituted by two each of metal atoms, ligands and TPA units, and 12 uncoordinated water molecules, whereas that of 2 is constituted by four each of Zn­(II) centers, ligands and TPA units, one DMF molecule, and 16 uncoordinated water molecules. The unit cell volumes of 2 and 3 are less than that of 1 by 4%. In all cases, the metal centers have distorted octahedral coordination geometry with MO4N2 configuration. Further, in all three complexes, one of the carboxylates of TPA is involved in the formation of bimetallic SBU (M2­(COO)2) with a metal-to-metal separation of about 4 Å while the other carboxylate links the SBUs via chelation of metal centers. As a result, the metal carboxylate layer containing rhomboidal cavities is formed in the bc-plane in 1 and 3 and in the ab-plane in 2. The grids are more rhomboidal in 1 (18.4 × 12.6 Å2) than in 2 and 3 (16.8 × 13.6 Å2). These layers are interlinked to the 3D-network with the double pillaring of the layers by L units such that the interlayer separation is of 18 Å in 1 and 16.4 Å in 2 and 3. The huge channels of the 3D-network are partially filled by double interpenetration. The interpenetration occurs through insertion of two of the L units (double pillar) into each and every rhomboidal cavity of the metal-terephthalate layers. The double pillar units of L are formed via π–π interactions with a plane-to-plane separation of 3.6–3.7 Å. The interpenetration creates channels along the c-axis in the case of 1 and 3 and along the a-axis in the case of 2. The representation of the network as nodes and spacers by reducing the SBUs as six connected nodes and double pillars as spacers illustrates the doubly interpenetrated 3D-pcu network ().

elements.content: All three MOFs are found to have 26% void space (PLATON) that are occupied solely by water molecules in 1 and 3 and by water and DMF in 2. These guest molecules were located and refined in 1 and 2 but could not be located in 3. The central pyridine of L in all three cases remains uncoordinated; in 1, the pyridine units of both the ligands are involved in O-H···N (O···N: 2.870 and 3.055 Å) hydrogen bonding with the channeled water molecules. In 2, three of the four pyridine moieties have such O-H···N (O···N: 2.849, 2.903, 2.891 Å) hydrogen bonding and the fourth one has close proximity to the electrophilic C atom of DMF (C···N: 3.337 Å).

In 2, three of the four pyridine moieties have such O-H⋅⋅⋅N (O⋅⋅⋅N: 2.849, 2.903, 2.891 Å) hydrogen bonding and the fourth one has close proximity to the electrophilic C atom of DMF (C⋅⋅⋅N: 3.337 Å).

elements.content: Interestingly, the channels that are formed between interpenetrated networks are filled by a column of hydrogen bonded water molecules in 1, whereas, in 2, they are occupied by the column of hydrogen bonded water and DMF molecules. In the case of 1, it forms a (H2O)12 cluster as repeating unit of the 1D-cage. The water cluster consists of two five-membered rings (A and B) and one each of six- (C) and four-membered rings (D). These clusters propagate as a 1D-cage by the formation of another six-membered ring (E) (). Among 12 water molecules, only one of it connects to four of its neighbors with distorted tetrahedral geometry (d O–O = 2.6, 2.8, 2.8, and 2.7 Å, ∠O–O–O = 86.7, 122.5, 107.2, and 117.7°) while the eight of them exhibit three connections with pyramidal geometries (d O–O = 2.6–3.0 Å and ∠O–O–O = 71.4–150.5°) and three exhibit two connections with angular geometry (d O–O = 2.6–2.7 Å and ∠O–O–O = 98.0–127.1°).

elements.content: In the case of 2, 16 water molecules and 1 DMF molecule form one-dimensional hydrogen bonded columns that are occupied in the channels. The repeating unit (H2O)16·DMF consists of a decalin-like unit that is fused to one five-membered ring (X) and one four-membered ring (Y). The O atom of DMF is part of the four-membered ring, and the hydrophobic portion of the DMF remains at the edge of the column and places itself into the networks (). In 2, similar to 1, only one water molecule forms four connections (d O–O = 2.8, 2.7, 2.8, and 2.7 Å, ∠O–O–O = 102.1, 83.1, 126.4, and 104.3°), six water molecules form three connections (d O–O = 2.6–2.9 Å, ∠O–O–O = 90.9–120.6°), and seven water molecules form two-connections (d O–O = 2.6 to 2.9 Å and ∠O–O–O = 85.1–119.3°).

elements.content: We note here that similar pcu networks with some dicarboxylates and bis-pyridyl ligands have been reported earlier but they have not exhibited the propensity for inclusion of water clusters/cages as observed here. These results are evident for the hydrophilicity of the channels given the presence of imidazole moieties in addition to carboxylates in the network. It is note worthy that the L is serving as a linear linker, although it has a curved structure and also exhibits higher interlayer (metal-terephthalate) separation (18 Å) than the previously reported examples (10–15 Å).

elements.content: To examine the stability of these materials, thermogrametric analysis has been carried out in the temperature range of 30–600 °C under a N2 atmosphere with 10 °C/min heating rate. It shows that all the three materials are stable up to 400 °C. At 150 °C, an initial weight loss of 12% corresponding to nine water molecules was observed for MOFs 1 and 3. For MOF 2, the same 12% weight loss was observed at 150 °C that may correspond to 16 water molecules or 13 water and DMF (Figure S8). The bulk purities of the samples were verified by comparison of experimental and simulated XRPD patterns (Figures S2–S4).

elements.content: Materials with water adsorption ability are important for many applications such as dehumidifiers, thermal batteries, adsorption driven heat exchangers, adsorption based heat pumps, etc. The poor stabilities of the MOFs in water and in humidity are worrisome factors for their usage as dehumidifiers. Although zeolites are good in water sorption, they are not good in sorbing other gases which are nonpolar in nature, whereas MOFs can fulfill both these purposes provided they are water stable.
elements.clean_text:
Water Sorption Studies

Materials with water adsorption ability are important for many applications such as dehumidifiers, thermal batteries, adsorption driven heat exchangers, adsorption based heat pumps, etc. The poor stabilities of the MOFs in water and in humidity are worrisome factors for their usage as dehumidifiers. Although zeolites are good in water sorption, they are not good in sorbing other gases which are nonpolar in nature, whereas MOFs can fulfill both these purposes provided they are water stable.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that all the three MOFs presented here were found to be water stable as verified by the XRPD of samples dipped in water at room temperature for 24 h. This kind of stability in water encouraged us to study the water vapor adsorption isotherm at room temperature. The MOFs are activated by immersing them in methanol for 7 days, followed by heating under vacuum at 150 °C for 3 h. The activated MOFs exhibit a gradual uptake of water given the hydrophilic nature of the channels. The H2O adsorption profile for all the MOFs was found to be of type-II, and the H2O vapors uptake in MOFs 1–3 is found to be 195, 224, and 184 cc/g (up to P/P 0 = 0.9), respectively (). These adsorption amounts by MOFs 1–3 correlate to 9.15, 10, and 8.21 mmol/g, respectively. XRPD patterns suggest that crystalline frameworks remain unchanged after the experiment. The type-II isotherm and uptake amounts reaffirm the hydrophilic channels of the MOFs 1–3. The observed water uptake capacities by these MOFs are found to be significantly better than those of many reported porous CPs or MOFs (Table S2).

elements.content: The presence of porous channels and water stability of the MOFs of complexes 1–3 prompted us to examine the permanent porosity of the frameworks by CO2, N2, and CH4 gas sorption measurements. To generate the fully desolvated framework, all the complexes were first immersed in methanol for 7 days, followed by heating under high vacuum at 150 °C. At 77 K, activated MOFs 1–3 exhibit a type-III adsorption profile with N2 gas and the uptakes amounts were found to be 55, 45, and 55 cc/g, respectively, even at high pressure (P/P 0 = 0.9).
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Studies

The presence of porous channels and water stability of the MOFs of complexes 1-3 prompted us to examine the permanent porosity of the frameworks by CO2, N2, and CH4 gas sorption measurements. To generate the fully desolvated framework, all the complexes were first immersed in methanol for 7 days, followed by heating under high vacuum at 150 °C. At 77 K, activated MOFs 1-3 exhibit a type-III adsorption profile with N2 gas and the uptakes amounts were found to be 55, 45, and 55 cc/g, respectively, even at high pressure (P/P 0 = 0.9).

elements.content: In contrast, the CO2 sorption at 273 K by MOFs displays a steep rise at the relatively low pressure region, which can be categorized as a type-I adsorption profile. The CO2 uptake capacities of complexes 1–3 are 69 (13.5 wt %), 68 (13.4 wt %), and 68 cc/g (13.1 wt %), respectively, at 273 K (a). The surface areas are found to be 256.35, 252.96, and 245.85 m2/g. The pore size distributions are calculated by the Horvath–Kawazoe model are in the range from 4.6 to 7.5 Å. The MOF 2 was found to exhibit a larger desorption hysteresis for CO2 that implies stronger interactions of CO2 with the framework compared to the other two frameworks. The desorption hysteresis mainly correlates with the narrow channel system that actually resists the departure of adsorbed gas molecules. The maximum CO2 uptakes by MOFs 1–3 are found to be 40, 18, and 62 cc/g at 298 K (c). The heat of adsorption (Q st) of CO2 sorption isotherms was calculated at 273 and 298 K by using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation. At zero coverage, the Q st values (−ΔH) for MOFs 1–3 are found to be 27, 32, and 32 kJ/mol. At high coverage, they exhibit 14, 35, and 15 kJ/mol (e). The MOF 2 was found to show larger desorption hysteresis for CO2 that correlated with the large Q st value. To further explore the potentiality of these MOFs under ambient conditions, the CH4 adsorption isotherms of MOFs 1–3 are measured at 298 K. The amounts of CH4 taken up are found to be 10, 3, and 14 cc/g, which are less compared to those of CO2 sorption (d). These gas sorption experiments reveal that the MOFs have CO2/N2 or CO2/CH4 selectivity and high loading affinity toward CO2. The selectivity of CO2 gas over N2 could be due to the better interactions of CO2 given its large quadrupole moment with the hydrophilic channels of MOFs than N2. Further, CO2 sorption capacities of the MOFs observed here are on par or better than those of many recently reported MOFs (Table S1).

elements.content: The MOFs with luminescent properties are of great interest due to their applicability in light emitting diodes (LEDs), photochemistry, and sensors. Generally, the Cd­(II) or Zn­(II) complexes are expected to exhibit interesting luminescence properties. Therefore, the solid state luminescence of the MOFs 1, 2 and L were recorded under the identical conditions at room temperature. The complexes of 1, 2 and L exhibit an emission maximum at about 440, 425, and 472 nm, respectively, upon excitation at 335 nm (). These could be attributed to the intraligand π–π* transitions of the ligand. In all of these MOFs, the ligands act as double pillar and form π–π interactions between azabenzimidazole moieties with a separation of 3.6–3.7 Å. The emission peaks for complexes 1 and 2 are blue-shifted compared to that of L. The blue shift in the emission maximum may be attributed to the M–L coordination bonds and also to the encapsulated lattice solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Studies

The MOFs with luminescent properties are of great interest due to their applicability in light emitting diodes (LEDs), photochemistry, and sensors. Generally, the Cd(II) or Zn(II) complexes are expected to exhibit interesting luminescence properties. Therefore, the solid state luminescence of the MOFs 1, 2 and L were recorded under the identical conditions at room temperature. The complexes of 1, 2 and L exhibit an emission maximum at about 440, 425, and 472 nm, respectively, upon excitation at 335 nm (). These could be attributed to the intraligand π-π* transitions of the ligand. In all of these MOFs, the ligands act as double pillar and form π-π interactions between azabenzimidazole moieties with a separation of 3.6-3.7 Å. The emission peaks for complexes 1 and 2 are blue-shifted compared to that of L. The blue shift in the emission maximum may be attributed to the M-L coordination bonds and also to the encapsulated lattice solvent molecules.

elements.content: Organic dyes are widely employed in textile, plastic, paint, leather, and paper industries, which, on the other hand, leads to serious environmental pollution due to their high toxicity to aquatic creatures and carcinogenic effects to human health. Therefore, the removal of dye pollutants is a crucial step during the treatment of factory sewage. MOFs/PCPs are promising candidates for selective adsorption of pollutants given their porosities, high surface areas, and presence of active sites. Ideally, dye-adsorbing agents should have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic domains for efficient dye removal. The presence of huge channels that are occupied by the water cluster in the MOFs 1–3 prompted us to explore their sorption abilities of cationic dye, namely, methylene blue (MB) and crystal violet (CV). Typical adsorption experiment was carried out by immersing freshly prepared samples of complexes 1–3 in the aqueous solution of MB (10–5 (M) concentration). The dye sorption was monitored by UV–vis spectrometry at various time intervals. The UV–vis indicates a gradual decrease of MB concentrations from aqueous solution with time, indicating sorption of the MB by the immersed materials of 1–3 (). This adsorption phenomenon can also be monitored by the naked eye as MB solution loses the blueness with time as well as the colorless crystals turn blue. This indicates that complexes 1–3 can effectively remove cationic dyes from water.
elements.clean_text:
Dye Adsorption Studies

Organic dyes are widely employed in textile, plastic, paint, leather, and paper industries, which, on the other hand, leads to serious environmental pollution due to their high toxicity to aquatic creatures and carcinogenic effects to human health. Therefore, the removal of dye pollutants is a crucial step during the treatment of factory sewage. MOFs/PCPs are promising candidates for selective adsorption of pollutants given their porosities, high surface areas, and presence of active sites. Ideally, dye-adsorbing agents should have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic domains for efficient dye removal. The presence of huge channels that are occupied by the water cluster in the MOFs 1-3 prompted us to explore their sorption abilities of cationic dye, namely, methylene blue (MB) and crystal violet (CV). Typical adsorption experiment was carried out by immersing freshly prepared samples of complexes 1-3 in the aqueous solution of MB (10-5 (M) concentration). The dye sorption was monitored by UV-vis spectrometry at various time intervals. The UV-vis indicates a gradual decrease of MB concentrations from aqueous solution with time, indicating sorption of the MB by the immersed materials of 1-3 (). This adsorption phenomenon can also be monitored by the naked eye as MB solution loses the blueness with time as well as the colorless crystals turn blue. This indicates that complexes 1-3 can effectively remove cationic dyes from water.

elements.content: Three water stable porous MOFs of Cd­(II), Zn­(II), and Co­(II) containing a pyridine 3,5-bis­(5-aza­benz­imidazole) ligand with linear dicarboxylate (sodium terephthalate) as linkers have been designed and synthesized. All three MOFs contain M2­(COO)2 SBUs that leads to the formation of a two-dimensional grid structure of metal and dicarboxylate. These 2D-networks are joined by ligand L, leading to form water stable pcu networks that are doubly interpenetrated. The channels of the network are occupied by the clusters of water molecules that are hydrogen bonded. The water clusters have different geometries in 1 and 2: MOF 1 exhibits more symmetric (H2O)12 as repeating cluster, whereas MOF 2 exhibits (H2O)16 and DMF cluster. The MOFs exhibit selective adsorption of CO2 over N2 and CH4 gases and efficient water vapor sorption due to the presence of channels containing polar functional groups. The presence of π–π stacking interactions between the networks resulted in the intense luminescence properties. Further, they have also shown the capability of sorbing the cationic dye from their aqueous solutions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three water stable porous MOFs of Cd(II), Zn(II), and Co(II) containing a pyridine 3,5-bis(5-azabenzimidazole) ligand with linear dicarboxylate (sodium terephthalate) as linkers have been designed and synthesized. All three MOFs contain M2(COO)2 SBUs that leads to the formation of a two-dimensional grid structure of metal and dicarboxylate. These 2D-networks are joined by ligand L, leading to form water stable pcu networks that are doubly interpenetrated. The channels of the network are occupied by the clusters of water molecules that are hydrogen bonded. The water clusters have different geometries in 1 and 2: MOF 1 exhibits more symmetric (H2O)12 as repeating cluster, whereas MOF 2 exhibits (H2O)16 and DMF cluster. The MOFs exhibit selective adsorption of CO2 over N2 and CH4 gases and efficient water vapor sorption due to the presence of channels containing polar functional groups. The presence of π-π stacking interactions between the networks resulted in the intense luminescence properties. Further, they have also shown the capability of sorbing the cationic dye from their aqueous solutions.

elements.content: All the chemicals, such as 3,4-diamino pyridine, pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid, poly­phos­phoric acid (PPA), terephthalic acid, N,N′-dimethyl­formamide, N,N′-dimethyl­acetamide, and metal salts, were purchased from local chemical suppliers and used without purification. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX400 spectrometer, and IR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Instrument Spectrum Rx Serial No. 73713. Melting points were taken using a Fisher Scientific melting point apparatus, cat. no. 12-144-1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were recorded with a Bruker D8-advance diffractometer at room temperature. The solid state luminescence spectra were collected with a Spex Fluorolog-3 (model FL3-22) spectrofluorimeter. The gas and solvent sorption experiments were performed using a micromeritics and Quantacrome autosorb iQ automated gas sorption analyzer. The solution state absorbance spectra were recorded with the use of a Shimadzu (model no. UV-2450) UV–vis spectrophotometer.

Experimental Section

NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX400 spectrometer, and IR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Instrument Spectrum Rx Serial No. 73713. Melting points were taken using a Fisher Scientific melting point apparatus, cat. no. 12-144-1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were recorded with a Bruker D8-advance diffractometer at room temperature. The solid state luminescence spectra were collected with a Spex Fluorolog-3 (model FL3-22) spectrofluorimeter. The gas and solvent sorption experiments were performed using a micromeritics and Quantacrome autosorb iQ automated gas sorption analyzer. The solution state absorbance spectra were recorded with the use of a Shimadzu (model no. UV-2450) UV-vis spectrophotometer.

elements.content:
The compound L was synthesized using the procedure reported by us earlier.

Synthesis of MOFs <bold>1</bold>–<bold>3</bold>

A mixture of L (0.010 g, 0.0323 mmol), sodium terephthalate (0.068 g, 0.0323 mmol), Cd­(NO3)2 (0.099 g, 0.0323 mmol), 2 mL of DMF, and 8 mL of water was taken in a sealed glass tube. The mixture was heated at 100 °C and then slowly cooled down to room temperature. After 2 days, colorless crystals of complex 1 were obtained, which were washed with water several times and dried in air. Yield 80%.

elements.content: A Micromeritics and Quantacrome autosorb surface area analyzer were used to measure gas and water sorption isotherms. For obtaining a guest-free framework, the fresh as-synthesized samples of complexes 1–3 were washed with distilled water then dried in air. After that, they were immersed in MeOH for 7 days to obtain MeOH incorporated materials, and the resultant solid was vacuumed at room temperature for 24 h and then activated at 150 °C for overnight prior to gas sorption measurements. The N2 sorption measurement was maintained at 77 K with liquid nitrogen. The CO2 sorption measurements were performed at 273 K with an ice–water bath. The activated samples of complexes 1–3 were used for the sorption measurements. Water vapor adsorption measurements were carried out at 298 K with a water bath. In the case of water adsorption, these samples were activated at 150 °C for 3 h prior to the experiment.
elements.clean_text:
Gas and Water Sorption Measurements

A Micromeritics and Quantacrome autosorb surface area analyzer were used to measure gas and water sorption isotherms. For obtaining a guest-free framework, the fresh as-synthesized samples of complexes 1-3 were washed with distilled water then dried in air. After that, they were immersed in MeOH for 7 days to obtain MeOH incorporated materials, and the resultant solid was vacuumed at room temperature for 24 h and then activated at 150 °C for overnight prior to gas sorption measurements. The N2 sorption measurement was maintained at 77 K with liquid nitrogen. The CO2 sorption measurements were performed at 273 K with an ice-water bath. The activated samples of complexes 1-3 were used for the sorption measurements. Water vapor adsorption measurements were carried out at 298 K with a water bath. In the case of water adsorption, these samples were activated at 150 °C for 3 h prior to the experiment.

elements.content: All of the single crystal data were collected on a Bruker-APEX-II CCD X-ray diffractometer that uses graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at temperature (150 K) by the hemisphere method. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by least-squares methods on F 2 using SHELX-2014. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model. The H atoms attached to the O atom or N atoms are located wherever possible and refined using the riding model. The solvent molecules in 3 could not be located and refined; therefore, the final refinement was done using PLATON squeeze option.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determinations by Single Crystal X-ray

All of the single crystal data were collected on a Bruker-APEX-II CCD X-ray diffractometer that uses graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at temperature (150 K) by the hemisphere method. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by least-squares methods on F 2 using SHELX-2014. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model. The H atoms attached to the O atom or N atoms are located wherever possible and refined using the riding model. The solvent molecules in 3 could not be located and refined; therefore, the final refinement was done using PLATON squeeze option.

cln_elements.content:
The compound L was synthesized using the procedure reported by us earlier.

Synthesis of MOFs <bold>1</bold>–<bold>3</bold>

A mixture of L (0.010 g, 0.0323 mmol), sodium terephthalate (0.068 g, 0.0323 mmol), Cd­(NO3)2 (0.099 g, 0.0323 mmol), 2 mL of DMF, and 8 mL of water was taken in a sealed glass tube. The mixture was heated at 100 °C and then slowly cooled down to room temperature. After 2 days, colorless crystals of complex 1 were obtained, which were washed with water several times and dried in air. Yield 80%.

A mixture of L (0.010 g, 0.0323 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.054 g, 0.0323 mmol), Zn­(NO3)2 (0.094 g, 0.0323 mmol), 3 mL of DMF, and 7 mL of water was taken in a sealed glass tube. The mixture was heated at 100 °C and then slowly cooled down to room temperature. After 2 days, colorless crystals of complex 2 were obtained, which were washed with water several times and dried in air. Yield 75%.

A mixture of L (0.010 g, 0.0323 mmol), terephthalic acid (0.054 g, 0.0323 mmol), Co­(NO3)2 (0.084 g, 0.0323 mmol), 2 mL of DMA, and 8 mL of water was taken in a sealed glass tube. The mixture was heated at 100 °C and then slowly cooled down to room temperature. After 2 days, single crystals of complexes 3 were obtained, which were washed with water several times and dried in air. Yield 80%.

cln_elements.content:
A rigid pyridine-3,5-bis­(5-aza­benz­imidazole) ligand (L) and linear dicarboxylate sodium terephthalate (TPA) with Cd­(II), Zn­(II), and Co­(II) under solvothermal conditions afforded water stable and nitrogen-rich MOFs with general formulas [Cd2 L 2­(TPA)2]·12H2O} n , 1, {[Zn4 L 4­(TPA)4]·(DMF)·16H2O} n , 2, and {[Co2 L 2­(TPA)2]·12H2O} n , 3, respectively. These MOFs are found to contain doubly interpenetrated pcu networks with hydrophilic channels. The networks are propagated by M2­(CO2)2 SBUs (intermetallic distances 4.0 Å) which leads to the formation of a two-dimensional grid structure of metal-terephthalate. The shape of grids varies from rhomboidal to squaric depending on the presence of a metal center. The channels of these MOFs are occupied by the one-dimensional water cages. In the pcu network, each cuboid is found to have dimensions of ∼12.5 Å as width and 18.5 Å as length. They have shown an excellent ability for water vapor sorption (180–225 cc/g at 298 K). Further, CO2 is found to be the preferred sorbent (70 cc/g at 273 K) over N2. They were also shown to be capable of dye (methylene blue and crystal violet) removal from aqueous solutions through adsorption. Further, Cd­(II) and Zn­(II) MOFs are found to exhibit solid state luminescence properties.

To examine the stability of these materials, thermogrametric analysis has been carried out in the temperature range of 30–600 °C under a N2 atmosphere with 10 °C/min heating rate. It shows that all the three materials are stable up to 400 °C. At 150 °C, an initial weight loss of 12% corresponding to nine water molecules was observed for MOFs 1 and 3. For MOF 2, the same 12% weight loss was observed at 150 °C that may correspond to 16 water molecules or 13 water and DMF (Figure S8). The bulk purities of the samples were verified by comparison of experimental and simulated XRPD patterns (Figures S2–S4).

It is noteworthy that all the three MOFs presented here were found to be water stable as verified by the XRPD of samples dipped in water at room temperature for 24 h. This kind of stability in water encouraged us to study the water vapor adsorption isotherm at room temperature. The MOFs are activated by immersing them in methanol for 7 days, followed by heating under vacuum at 150 °C for 3 h. The activated MOFs exhibit a gradual uptake of water given the hydrophilic nature of the channels. The H2O adsorption profile for all the MOFs was found to be of type-II, and the H2O vapors uptake in MOFs 1–3 is found to be 195, 224, and 184 cc/g (up to P/P 0 = 0.9), respectively (). These adsorption amounts by MOFs 1–3 correlate to 9.15, 10, and 8.21 mmol/g, respectively. XRPD patterns suggest that crystalline frameworks remain unchanged after the experiment. The type-II isotherm and uptake amounts reaffirm the hydrophilic channels of the MOFs 1–3. The observed water uptake capacities by these MOFs are found to be significantly better than those of many reported porous CPs or MOFs (Table S2).

Gas Sorption Studies

The presence of porous channels and water stability of the MOFs of complexes 1–3 prompted us to examine the permanent porosity of the frameworks by CO2, N2, and CH4 gas sorption measurements. To generate the fully desolvated framework, all the complexes were first immersed in methanol for 7 days, followed by heating under high vacuum at 150 °C. At 77 K, activated MOFs 1–3 exhibit a type-III adsorption profile with N2 gas and the uptakes amounts were found to be 55, 45, and 55 cc/g, respectively, even at high pressure (P/P 0 = 0.9).

In contrast, the CO2 sorption at 273 K by MOFs displays a steep rise at the relatively low pressure region, which can be categorized as a type-I adsorption profile. The CO2 uptake capacities of complexes 1–3 are 69 (13.5 wt %), 68 (13.4 wt %), and 68 cc/g (13.1 wt %), respectively, at 273 K (a). The surface areas are found to be 256.35, 252.96, and 245.85 m2/g. The pore size distributions are calculated by the Horvath–Kawazoe model are in the range from 4.6 to 7.5 Å. The MOF 2 was found to exhibit a larger desorption hysteresis for CO2 that implies stronger interactions of CO2 with the framework compared to the other two frameworks. The desorption hysteresis mainly correlates with the narrow channel system that actually resists the departure of adsorbed gas molecules. The maximum CO2 uptakes by MOFs 1–3 are found to be 40, 18, and 62 cc/g at 298 K (c). The heat of adsorption (Q st) of CO2 sorption isotherms was calculated at 273 and 298 K by using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation. At zero coverage, the Q st values (−ΔH) for MOFs 1–3 are found to be 27, 32, and 32 kJ/mol. At high coverage, they exhibit 14, 35, and 15 kJ/mol (e). The MOF 2 was found to show larger desorption hysteresis for CO2 that correlated with the large Q st value. To further explore the potentiality of these MOFs under ambient conditions, the CH4 adsorption isotherms of MOFs 1–3 are measured at 298 K. The amounts of CH4 taken up are found to be 10, 3, and 14 cc/g, which are less compared to those of CO2 sorption (d). These gas sorption experiments reveal that the MOFs have CO2/N2 or CO2/CH4 selectivity and high loading affinity toward CO2. The selectivity of CO2 gas over N2 could be due to the better interactions of CO2 given its large quadrupole moment with the hydrophilic channels of MOFs than N2. Further, CO2 sorption capacities of the MOFs observed here are on par or better than those of many recently reported MOFs (Table S1).

Luminescence Studies

The MOFs with luminescent properties are of great interest due to their applicability in light emitting diodes (LEDs), photochemistry, and sensors. Generally, the Cd­(II) or Zn­(II) complexes are expected to exhibit interesting luminescence properties. Therefore, the solid state luminescence of the MOFs 1, 2 and L were recorded under the identical conditions at room temperature. The complexes of 1, 2 and L exhibit an emission maximum at about 440, 425, and 472 nm, respectively, upon excitation at 335 nm (). These could be attributed to the intraligand π–π* transitions of the ligand. In all of these MOFs, the ligands act as double pillar and form π–π interactions between azabenzimidazole moieties with a separation of 3.6–3.7 Å. The emission peaks for complexes 1 and 2 are blue-shifted compared to that of L. The blue shift in the emission maximum may be attributed to the M–L coordination bonds and also to the encapsulated lattice solvent molecules.
